Award.AwardTitle: RUI: Searching for WIMP Dark Matter With Superheated Liquids
Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual Merit: One of the great mysteries in astrophysics is the nature of dark matter, which is currently only detected indirectly through its effects on the structuring of galaxies, clusters of galaxies and larger scale structures in the universe. Generic extensions of the standard model of subatomic particles predict the existence of Weakly Interacting Massive Particles (WIMPS), which are excellent candidates for the dark matter. These are expected to interact with ordinary matter rarely and thus be extremely difficult to detect. The COUPP and PICASSO groups are developing new large dark matter detectors derived from the well-known bubble chamber technique. Charged particles traversing the superheated fluid in bubble chambers deposit heat, which creates small bubbles of gas. The bubbles can be photographed before pressurization revealing the paths of these particles. Other non-dark matter triggers can also lead to runaway boiling. These have limited classical chambers to remain in a superheated state for only a short time. The COUPP experiment has paid special attention to material selection and manufacturing techniques to remove roughness and radiocontamination to allow the superheated state to be long lived. The PICASSO experiment suspends superheated fluid droplets in a gel whose surfaces are so smooth that the droplets can stay in a superheated state indefinitely. Both experiments have made the superheated state sufficiently long lived to search for dark matter.

This award will allow the PI to continue his work on the COUPP and PICASSO experiments. The sound sensors produced by the Indiana University group have been used for rejecting cosmic ray induced events and distinguishing the radioactive signals for moderately superheated fluids. The PI and his students have built equipment to test the sound sensors under realistic conditions mimicking those in the detectors and to measure changes in their sensitivity as a function of age. The group has also taken on the task of measuring contaminants in the fluid target and is now prepared to routinely assay the fluid.

Broader impacts: Enhancing the education of undergraduates is an integral part of this program. Undergraduates, high school teachers and students have participated in design, construction and characterization of acoustic transducers, measurement of radioactivity, and other projects. In addition, the PI and his group has provided acoustic sensors to other scientific groups to assist in other experiments.

POR.DRECONTENT:
One of the most enduring mysteries in astrophysics is the explanation for the compelling evidence that about 85% of gravitating material exists in an intrinsically invisible form. This "dark matter" is detected indirectly through its effects on visible matter. For example, stars orbit galaxies so fast and galaxies move in clusters so fast, that if the atoms were the only matter in them, these systems would fly apart. Dark matters’ presence affected the types of atoms created during the Big Bang, bends light passing through clusters, etc.

 

The nature of this dark matter is not yet known. Interestingly, most theoretical attempts to extend our understanding of elementary particles predict, as a side benefit, the existence of massive, electrically neutral particles which would have just the properties required of dark matter. The PICASSO and COUPP experiments (which have joined to form the “PICO” collaboration) are attempting to find these Weakly Interacting Massive Particles (WIMPS). We prepare atomic targets for the dark matter passing through us-unseen-, and use a special amplification trick observe the tiny energy transferred to the atoms, on the rare occasions that collisions occur.

 

PICO exploits the almost 70 year-old bubble chamber technique.  Recoiling nuclei, traversing the superheated fluids (liquids raised above their boiling temperature), deposit heat. This creates bubbles of gas. These bubbles expand explosively unless the chamber is quickly pressurized. The bubbles can be photographed and the associated acoustic emissions can be sensed, so the chamber is an excellent amplifier of tiny energy signals.  Traditionally, other sources of bubbles (trapped gas on rough surfaces and gaskets, radioactive contamination, etc.) also led to runaway boiling. This allowed classical chambers to remain in this superheated state for only a short time (about one thousandth of a second), making them unsuitable for rare event searches. PICO has taken the approach of paying special attention to material selection and fabrication techniques to remove roughness and radioactive contamination to allow the superheated state to be extremely long-lived.

 

Having just overcome a background from dust particulates, PICO is now the most sensitive detector of dark matter candidates coupling dominantly to proton spin. (Figure 4)

 

The PI used this NSF support to continue his participation and that of his students in these efforts. IUSB’s main responsibilities are the design and fabrication of the acoustic sensing system The acoustics are important because we discovered in 2008 (Figure 1) that they can be used to distinguish, on an event-by-event basis, bubbles created by nuclear recoils (the signal) from those initiated by radioactive decay (background). During the period of this grant, our team developed a technique to distinguish radioactive decays of different energy by their different acoustic signatures (Figure 2). We also improved the durability of the acoustic transducers to better survive the challenging conditions of the experiment, via improved mechanical design of the transducer body and modifications to the embedded preamplifier circuit. We have fabricated approximately 1000 acoustic transducers for all detectors in the PICASSO, COUPP and PICO experiments, including numerous test chambers and calibration chambers used in accelerator beam-lines.

 

We also developed a system to mimic the physical conditions in the bubble chambers to test all detector components and materials for potential operational or chemical problems. We chemically broke down samples of the target fluid CF3I and incorporated the carbon into molecules of CO2 to allow a measurement of the fraction of carbon14 in the target. IUSB has also conducted measurement of the chemical purity of all detector fluids and developed a technique to measure the light metal content of candidate detector materials which could contribute background. The postdoctoral researcher in our group was chosen as the analysis coordinator and he discovered an unexpected background, which has now been mitigated. This postdoctoral researcher helped guide analysis projects by two IUSB undergraduate students who developed the acoustic analysis of particulate background events and an improved event display/analysis package for the collaboration.

 

 

Enhancing the education of undergraduates and high school teachers is an integral part of this program. Forty undergraduates have participated in the work at IUSB as have 5 high school teachers and 5 high school students. They have participated in design, construction and characterization of acoustic transducers, measurement of radioactivity and other projects for the experiments. Fifteen have contributed enough to present their work at national and international conferences and have been co-authors of refereed papers by COUPP, PICASSO and PICO.  

 

In addition, the IUSB group has provided acoustic sensors to 3 other scientific groups: The Fermilab accelerator division uses them to help them understand electrical breakdown in a muon accelerator system. An Argonne Laboratories-led astrophysics experiment, studying exotic reactions relevant to large stars, uses them to distinguish competing processes in a water bubble chamber, and a competing dark matter search experiment (LUX) used them to discard events polluted by boiling cryogenic fluids.
